rev.comment: /* National Police Day protests */ fixed wikilink
rev.diff:
Line 100: Line 100:
Opposition groups were planning a day of revolt for January 25, coinciding with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The goal for the protests was to protest against abuses by the police in front of the ministry of interior.<ref>{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood to participate in 25 January protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/muslim-brotherhood-participate-25-january-protest|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> These demands expanded to be the resignation of the minister of Interior, the restoration of a fair minimum wage, the end of Emergency Law and the limitation of the presidency to two terms. A major supporter for the protests was the [[April 6 Youth Movement]], which distributed 20,000 leaflets saying "I will protest on 25 January to get my rights".
Opposition groups were planning a day of revolt for January 25, coinciding with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The goal for the protests was to protest against abuses by the police in front of the ministry of interior.<ref>{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood to participate in 25 January protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/muslim-brotherhood-participate-25-january-protest|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> These demands expanded to be the resignation of the minister of Interior, the restoration of a fair minimum wage, the end of Emergency Law and the limitation of the presidency to two terms. A major supporter for the protests was the [[April 6 Youth Movement]], which distributed 20,000 leaflets saying "I will protest on 25 January to get my rights".
â
Security forces however deemed the protests as "illegal", not having the required permissions to proceed and would therefore deal with it strictly.<ref>{{cite news|title=Security forces to deal strictly with 'illegal' 25 January protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/security-forces-deal-strictly-illegal-25-january-protest|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> Many political movements, opposition parties and public figures chose to support the day of revolt including [[Youth for Justice and Freedom]], the [[Popular Democratic Movement for Change]] and the [[National Association for Change]], however, its leader [[Mohamed El Baradei]] did not support doing protests saying that he "would like to use the means available from within the system to effect change".<ref>{{cite news|last=Shenker|first=Jack|title=Mohamed ElBaradei warns of 'Tunisia-style explosion' in Egypt|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/18/mohamed-elbaradei-tunisia-egypt|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Ghad party|Ghad]] , [[Karama party|Karama]], [[Wafd party|Wafd]] and [[Democratic Front party|Democratic Front]] parties also lend their support to the protests. Public figures including novelist [[Alaa Al Aswany]], writer [[Belal Fadl]] and actors [[Amr Waked]] and [[Khaled Aboul Naga]] announced they would also participate, while the facebook group set for the event attracted 80,000 attendees. However, the [[Tagammu Party]] and the Muslim brotherhood stated they would not participate. The Coptic church also urged Christians not to participate in the protests.<ref>{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Activists hope 25 January protest will be start of 'something big'|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
+
Security forces however deemed the protests as "illegal", not having the required permissions to proceed and would therefore deal with it strictly.<ref>{{cite news|title=Security forces to deal strictly with 'illegal' 25 January protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/security-forces-deal-strictly-illegal-25-january-protest|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=23 January 2011}}</ref> Many political movements, opposition parties and public figures chose to support the day of revolt including [[Youth for Justice and Freedom]], the [[Popular Democratic Movement for Change]] and the [[National Association for Change]], however, its leader [[Mohamed El Baradei]] did not support doing protests saying that he "would like to use the means available from within the system to effect change".<ref>{{cite news|last=Shenker|first=Jack|title=Mohamed ElBaradei warns of 'Tunisia-style explosion' in Egypt|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/18/mohamed-elbaradei-tunisia-egypt|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Ghad party|Ghad]] , [[Karama party|Karama]], [[Wafd party|Wafd]] and [[Democratic Front Party (Egypt)|Democratic Front]] parties also lend their support to the protests. Public figures including novelist [[Alaa Al Aswany]], writer [[Belal Fadl]] and actors [[Amr Waked]] and [[Khaled Aboul Naga]] announced they would also participate, while the facebook group set for the event attracted 80,000 attendees. However, the [[Tagammu Party]] and the Muslim brotherhood stated they would not participate. The Coptic church also urged Christians not to participate in the protests.<ref>{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Activists hope 25 January protest will be start of 'something big'|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
In a final attempt to calm the situation down, on January 24 the government announced they found the mastermind behind the [[2011 Alexandria bombing|Alexandria church bombing]], accusing the "[[Army of Islam (Gaza Strip)|Army of Islam]]" of planning the incident.<ref>{{cite news|last=El-Hennawy|first=Noha|title=Monday's papers: Alex bombing perpetrator announced, and Day of Loyalty vs Day of Revolt |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/mondays-papers-alex-bombing-perpetrator-announced-and-day-loyalty-vs-day-anger-0|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
In a final attempt to calm the situation down, on January 24 the government announced they found the mastermind behind the [[2011 Alexandria bombing|Alexandria church bombing]], accusing the "[[Army of Islam (Gaza Strip)|Army of Islam]]" of planning the incident.<ref>{{cite news|last=El-Hennawy|first=Noha|title=Monday's papers: Alex bombing perpetrator announced, and Day of Loyalty vs Day of Revolt |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/mondays-papers-alex-bombing-perpetrator-announced-and-day-loyalty-vs-day-anger-0|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
